Bitcoin found a way to eliminate trusted 3rd parties. Eliminating intermediaries was literally the breakthrough. By trusting Coinbase, you’ve brought the trusted 3rd party right back into the equation.

This is from 2014. Give it a read and you’ll see right away how much things have changed. The vision described here is why I evangelized Bitcoin for many years. https:// dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/01/21/why -bitcoin-matters/ …
I still hold #Bitcoin and I am paid exclusively in Bitcoin, but I’m disappointed in the way things turned out.
I am unbanked and had been relying on Bitcoin until it became completely unusable to me. I can’t afford $40 txn fees. Bitcoincash is just like Bitcoin used to be all of those years.
Exchanges are, for the most part, uninsured. Over 910,000 Bitcoin have been stolen from them over the years and users are generally SOL.

For regular wallets, Coinbase has complete control over your keys. That’s why Coinbase users where not able to receive their BitcoinCash until recently and they almost didn’t receive it all. Coinbase originally said no and then backpedaled after the fury.
I have always loved both #Bitcoin and Ripple. I see them as complimentary, not competitive. Ripple is a currency agnostic platform, after all.

You don’t have to explain yourself to me. I’m not sure which options are available to you, which is why I said to use the same method that you used to acquire them. Many people convert into Bitcoin before cashing out because there are more options that way.

When you hand your crypto over to an exchange, you are no longer in control. This is true for #Bitcoin just as much as it is for $ XRP . Coinbase freezing a customers acct is not the same as “All BItcoin can be frozen by Coinbase on a whim!” Whoever holds the keys, owns the crypto.

Bitcoin mining is the most raw, price-driven marketplace in the world. If those surpluses make the price of power in such places cheaper than anywhere else, miners will move there.

Sounds like important work. My point is that rising crypto prices will incentivize even more rapid advances in generation, storage and distribution networks, whether in solar, nuclear, or fossil fuels. That counters the simplistic bitcoin-will-destroy-the-planet narrative.

I should clarify: For the space fans out there, sadly I won't be touching on the otherwise intriguing idea of outer-space mining (though I think they are coming) but on the positive impact that a rising bitcoin price could have in incentivizing solar energy innovation.
